title: Our flawed democracy
text:
Delegates, from left, Rick Morris, Riley Ingram and Manoli Loupassi chat as lawmakers return to Richmond to kick off the 2015 Virginia General Assembly on Jan. 14. (Jahi Chikwendiu/The Washington Post) October 2 at 6:09 PM The Sept. 30 editorial “ The noncompete state ” painted one brush stroke on an immense canvas. I’m slowly getting used to living in a “one-man, one-vote democracy,” where political redistricting disenfranchises members of the party out of favor at census time by rendering their votes meaningless, where we disenfranchise the poor and disabled with clearly prejudiced and unnecessary election rules and, to amplify the effect of the latter, auction off the legislative process to the highest bidder.
When the Supreme Court justices distorted a century-old convention to make corporations members of the electorate, it seems they took the “supreme” part of their title more seriously than the “justice” part.
I sincerely hope that the brand of democracy we are trying to export to other countries is a wee bit better that the one we are building here.
Frank Arsenault , Annapolis
